column1: #Text=North Korea 's rising tensions : Wikinews interviews Scott Snyder and Dr Robert Kelly
#Text=In recent days , North Korea has been issuing threats of war to neighbouring South Korea and the United States .
#Text=There has been an increase in tensions as well as the decision to close off the Kaesong Industrial Park to South Korean workers .

#Text=interviewed Dr. Robert Kelly of Pusan National University ( PNU ) in South Korea , who specialises in security and diplomacy , about the recent threats ; and Scott Snyder , a North Korean specialist from the Council on Foreign Relations ( CFR ) in the United States .
#Text=I am a Professor of International Relations at PNU .
#Text=I am a senior fellow for Korea Studies and director of the program for U.S. – Korea policy at CFR .
#Text=North Korea has issued many threats to South Korea , how likely do you think it is that they will carry out these threats ?
#Text=North Korea would lose a war if one began , and if they use nuclear weapons , they will lose all sympathy in global opinion and China will abandon them .
#Text=The point of these threats is to shake-down SK [ South Korea ] and its new president for aid , not to start a war .
#Text=( Image missing from commons : image ; log )
#Text=: North Korea 's threats have a variety of purposes .

#Text=Some are defensive and are primarily meant to deter other countries from taking aggressive stances in the face of North Korea 's own weakness ; some are designed tactically to set up for negotiations ; some are expressions of intent or aspiration that are beyond the capability of North Korea to implement without facing severe consequences , and some are very specific threats that North Korea will attempt to implement as part of a guerrilla strategy so as to avoid escalation and take advantage of the element of surprise .
#Text=NK [ North Korean ] threats should be taken seriously , but evaluated carefully to determine circumstances under which they might actually be carried out .
#Text=How do people in South Korea feel about North Korea 's nuclear weapon 's programme ?
#Text=: They do not like it of course , but they worry far less about it than outsiders would expect .
#Text=South Koreans have been living under this shadow for many years .
#Text=The North has made many threats in the past .
#Text=So NK is like the boy who cried wolf .
#Text=No one expects them to launch a weapon .
#Text=Increasingly unsettled and concerned , especially about the possibility of being subject to nuclear blackmail .
#Text=At the same time , this circumstance thus far has had negligible impact on South Koreans ' daily lives .
